title: 112_s647
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Montana Mineral Conveyance Act". Congress finds that the Secretary of the Interior has conveyed mineral rights in large coal tracts near the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation, leading to substantial public revenues from energy developments in the area. The development of coal tracts and major energy resources near the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation generates significant public revenues for the State, aiding in addressing the impacts of development. Despite chronic economic challenges and deficits in public services, the Northern Cheyenne tribal community continues to struggle. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe does not benefit from public revenues generated by surrounding energy development, leading to economic challenges and deficits in public services. They lack revenue sources to address development impacts, prompting a lawsuit against the Secretary in 2002. In 2002, the Northern Cheyenne Tribe sued the Secretary over proposed conveyances of Federal coal tracts to the State, citing violations of Federal laws and trust responsibilities. The Tribe later withdrew the lawsuit with prejudice. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe withdrew a lawsuit against the Secretary with prejudice, based on commitments for legislation and funding to address coal development impacts. The Tribe retains claims against the United States. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe withdrew a lawsuit against the Secretary with prejudice, retaining claims against the United States for failure to acquire mineral rights on Reservation land. The Tribe seeks support for pursuing mineral rights conveyances with Great Northern Properties. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe will waive legal claims against the United States for mineral rights on Reservation land if conveyances are made with Great Northern Properties. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Cheyenne tracts" refers to a 5,000-acre land located in the eastern portion of the state within the Reservation boundaries, depicted on a map dated April 7, 2010. It consists of specific sections in T. 2 S., R. 44 E. The Cheyenne tracts, a 5,000-acre land within Reservation boundaries, consist of specific sections in T. 2 S., R. 44 E., including various lots in different sections. The Federal tracts are unleased land located in the State, outside Reservation boundaries, with specific sections and lots in different areas. The term "Federal tracts" refers to unleased land in the State, outside Reservation boundaries, consisting of approximately 5,000 acres and specific sections and lots in different areas. The term "Great Northern Properties" refers to the Great Northern Properties Limited Partnership, a Delaware limited partnership. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to land ownership, including "Great Northern Properties," "Reservation," "Secretary," and "State." The curr_chunk focuses on mineral rights conveyances. Great Northern Properties will convey mineral interests to the Tribe, and in return, the Secretary will convey coal rights to Great Northern Properties. The mineral interests conveyed to the Tribe will be immune from state taxation. SEC. 5. TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF MINERAL CONVEYANCES. In exchange for mineral conveyances, the Tribe must waive claims regarding the United States' failure to acquire private mineral interests. The Tribe and Great Northern Properties must agree on a revenue-sharing formula for coal production from Federal tracts. Mineral conveyances must be completed as specified. The Tribe and Great Northern Properties must agree on a revenue-sharing formula for coal production from Federal tracts. Mineral conveyances must be completed within 90 days of notifying the Secretary in writing. Rescission of mineral conveyances is also addressed. The mineral conveyances under section 4(a) must be completed within 90 days of notifying the Secretary in writing. If any portion of the conveyances is invalidated by a Federal district court and the judgment is not overturned on appeal, the Secretary or Great Northern Properties may rescind each conveyance. If a mineral conveyance under section 4(a) is invalidated by a Federal district court and not reversed on appeal, the Secretary or Great Northern Properties can rescind the conveyance. If rescinded, the waiver of the Tribe under subsection (a) is also considered rescinded. SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY FOR OTHER FEDERAL BENEFITS.

No benefits provided to the Tribe under this Act shall affect their eligibility for any Federal services or programs due to their status as a federally recognized Indian tribe or the status of any tribal member.

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Appropriations necessary to implement this Act are authorized.
